name: Preparation & Post-Op Care
pre_op_assessment:
1. Assessment & Optimization

  • History: Focus on cardiorespiratory reserve (METs - can they climb 2 flights of stairs?), previous anesthesia issues, and comorbidities (Diabetes, HTN).
  • Medications:
    - Stop: Warfarin (5 days pre-op), Clopidogrel (7 days), ACE inhibitors (morning of surgery - risk of hypotension), Oral Hypoglycemics.
    - Continue: Beta-blockers, Statins, Antiepileptics, Steroids (may need IV hydrocortisone stress dose).
  • Airway Exam: Mallampati Score (I-IV) to predict difficult intubation.
pre_op_investigations:
2. Routine Investigations

  • FBC: Anemia baseline. Platelets for spinal anesthesia.
  • U&E: K+ levels (arrhythmia risk). Creatinine (drug clearance).
  • Coagulation (PT/APTT): Only if history of bleeding or on anticoagulants.
  • Group & Save: Essential. Crossmatch blood if significant blood loss is anticipated.
  • ECG: Men >40, Women >50, or history of CVS disease.
  • CXR: Only if active respiratory disease or metastasis suspected.
pre_op_prep:
3. Patient Preparation

  • Consent: Must be Voluntary, Informed (risks/benefits), and with Capacity.
  • Fasting (NPO): '2-4-6 Rule'. 2h Clear Fluids, 4h Breast Milk, 6h Solids. Reduces aspiration pneumonitis (Mendelson's syndrome).
  • VTE Prophylaxis: Risk assessment (e.g., Caprini score). Mechanical (TED stockings/SCDs) + Chemical (LMWH e.g., Enoxaparin) usually 6-12h pre-op.
  • Antibiotics: Prophylactic dose given at induction (within 60 mins of incision).
  • Marking: Surgeon must mark the site while patient is awake.
post_op_immediate:
1. Immediate (Recovery Room/PACU)

Airway: Patency.
Breathing: RR, O2 Sats (maintain >94%).
Circulation: HR, BP, Urine Output (target >0.5ml/kg/hr). Check wound/drains for Primary Hemorrhage.
Disability: GCS, Pain score.
Exposure: Temperature (prevent hypothermia).
post_op_ward:
2. Ward Care (Day 0-3)

  • Fluids: Maintenance (25-30ml/kg/day) + Replacement of losses (drains/vomit). Stop IV when oral intake adequate.
  • Analgesia: WHO Ladder. Multi-modal (Paracetamol + NSAID + Opiate). PCA for major surgery.
  • Mobilization: Early ambulation reduces DVT, Pneumonia, and Ileus.
  • Drains: Monitor quality (blood/bile/pus) and quantity. Remove when <30ml/24h or as per protocol.
eras_protocol:
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS)

Evidence-based protocol to reduce stress response and hospital stay.
Pre-op: Counseling, Carb loading (no prolonged fasting), No bowel prep (colon surgery).
Intra-op: Short acting anesthetic, Avoid fluid overload, Minimally invasive approach.
Post-op: Early feeding (gut stimulation), Early mobilization, Opioid-sparing analgesia, Early catheter removal.
complications:
The 5 W's of Post-Op Fever

  • Day 1-2 (Wind): Atelectasis (commonest - collapsed alveoli due to pain/splinting). Rx: Physio/Analgesia. Pneumonia.
  • Day 3-5 (Water): UTI (Catheter associated). Rx: Remove catheter/Abx.
  • Day 5-7 (Wound): Surgical Site Infection (SSI). Rx: Drain pus/Abx. Anastomotic Leak (Tachycardia + Pain).
  • Day 7+ (Walk): DVT / PE. Rx: Anticoagulation.
  • Anytime (Wonder Drugs): Drug fever, Transfusion reaction, Cannula phlebitis.

name: Routine Biochemical Tests
hematology:
Full Blood Count (FBC)

  • Hemoglobin (Hb):
    - Microcytic: Iron deficiency (Chronic GI bleed) or Thalassemia.
    - Normocytic: Acute blood loss, Chronic disease.
    - Macrocytic: B12/Folate deficiency, Alcohol.
  • White Cell Count (WBC):
    - Neutrophilia: Bacterial infection, inflammation (Pancreatitis), Trauma (Surgery).
    - Lymphocytosis: Viral infection.
    - Leukopenia: Sepsis (marrow suppression), Chemo.
  • Platelets:
    - Thrombocytopenia (<150): Sepsis, DIC, Massive transfusion (dilution). Spontaneous bleeding risk <20.
biochemistry:
Urea & Electrolytes (U&E)

  • Creatinine: Specific for renal function.
  • Urea: Isolated Rise: Suggests Upper GI Bleed (digested blood protein) or Dehydration.
  • Potassium (K+):
    - Hyperkalemia (>5.5): EMERGENCY (Arrhythmia). Causes: Renal failure, Rhabdomyolysis, Acidosis. Rx: Calcium Gluconate (protect heart), Insulin/Dextrose (shift K+).
    - Hypokalemia (<3.5): Causes Ileus.
liver_profile:
Liver Function Tests (LFTs)

  • Bilirubin: Unconjugated (Pre-hepatic/Hemolysis) vs Conjugated (Post-hepatic/Obstruction).
  • Enzymes:
    - Hepatocellular: ALT/AST > ALP. (Hepatitis, Ischemia).
    - Cholestatic: ALP/GGT > ALT. (Gallstones, Cancer).
  • Synthetic Function:
    - Albumin: Long half-life (Chronic). Low in malnutrition/cirrhosis.
    - INR: Short half-life (Acute). Best marker for acute liver failure.
inflammatory:
Acute Phase Reactants

  • CRP: Lags 24h behind. CRP >150 at Day 3-4 post-op predicts Anastomotic Leak.
  • Amylase: >3x Upper Limit = Acute Pancreatitis.
  • Lipase: More specific for Pancreas.

name: Routine Imaging Studies
xray:
Plain Radiography

  • Chest X-ray (Erect): Gold standard for Pneumoperitoneum (free air under diaphragm) in perforated viscus.
  • Abdominal X-ray (Supine): Diagnostic for Intestinal Obstruction (dilated loops: Small bowel >3cm central; Large bowel >6cm peripheral). Poor for stones.
ultrasound:
Ultrasound (USG)

High-frequency sound waves. No radiation.
Uses: 1st line for Biliary (Stones), Renal (Hydronephrosis), Scrotal (Torsion), DVT (Doppler).
Limitations: Operator dependent. Cannot see through bowel gas or bone.
ct_scan:
CT Scan

X-ray slices. High radiation (1 CT = 400 CXRs).
Contrast: IV (Vessels/Organs) + Oral (Bowel). Check eGFR first (CIN risk).
Uses: Acute Abdomen (Diverticulitis, Appendicitis), Trauma (Pan-scan), Staging Cancer.
mri:
MRI

Magnetic fields. No radiation. Superior soft tissue contrast.
Uses: MRCP (Biliary tree), Rectal Cancer Staging, Perianal Fistula.
Contraindications: Pacemakers, Metal implants, Claustrophobia.

name: Endoscopic Procedures
upper_gi:
OGDS (Gastroscopy)

Visualizes Esophagus to D2.
Diagnostic: Ulcers, Cancer Biopsy, H. pylori CLO test.
Therapeutic: Variceal Banding, Adrenaline injection (Bleeding peptic ulcer).

ERCP

Side-viewing scope for Biliary tree.
Therapeutic: Sphincterotomy, Stone extraction, Stenting.
Risk: Pancreatitis (5%).
lower_gi:
Colonoscopy

Entire colon + terminal ileum.
Uses: CRC Screening, Polypectomy, IBD.
Risk: Perforation (1:1000).

Flexible Sigmoidoscopy

Rectum/Sigmoid only. Quick prep (Enema).
eus:
Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS)

US probe on scope tip.
Uses: T-Staging (depth) of Esophageal/Pancreatic Ca. FNA of mediastinal nodes.

name: Shock
definition:
Definition

Acute circulatory failure leading to inadequate tissue perfusion. Defined by perfusion (Lactate, Urine, Mental State), NOT just BP.
types:
• Hypovolemic: Loss of volume (Bleed/Burn). Preload ↓, CO ↓, SVR ↑.
  • Cardiogenic: Pump failure (MI). Preload ↑ (JVP), CO ↓, SVR ↑.
  • Obstructive: Physical block (Tension Pneumo/Tamponade). Preload ↑, CO ↓.
  • Distributive: Vasodilation (Sepsis/Anaphylaxis). Preload ↓, CO ↑ (early), SVR ↓↓↓.
management:
Priorities

1. Hypovolemic: Volume first! Warmed Crystalloids -> Blood (1:1:1 ratio).
2. Cardiogenic: Inotropes + Diuretics.
3. Septic: Fluids first -> Vasopressors (Noradrenaline).

name: Metabolic Response to Injury
phases:
1. Ebb Phase (0-24h)

'Shock phase'. Hypometabolism. Priority: Survival.

2. Flow Phase

'Catabolic phase'. Hypermetabolism. Muscle wasting (Gluconeogenesis). Insulin Resistance.

3. Recovery Phase

Anabolic. Protein restoration.
optimization:
Attenuating the Response

1. Analgesia: Blocks neural stimuli.
2. Early Nutrition: Prevents catabolism.
3. Temperature Control: Prevents coagulopathy.

name: Chemotherapy Principles
intent:
Classification

Neoadjuvant: Before surgery. To downstage (shrink) tumor.
Adjuvant: After surgery. To treat micrometastases/prevent recurrence.
Palliative: Symptom control only.
toxicity:
Neutropenic Sepsis

Definition: Temp >38°C + Neutrophils <0.5.
Action: Medical Emergency! Resuscitate + IV Broad Spectrum Abx (Tazocin) within 1 hour. Do NOT wait for blood results.

name: Sterilization & Disinfection
definitions:
Sterilization: Kills ALL organisms including Spores (Autoclave).
Disinfection: Reduces load, may not kill spores (Chlorhexidine/Iodine).
methods:
Autoclave (Moist Heat)

121°C for 15 mins. Gold standard for metal.

Glutaraldehyde

High-level disinfectant for Endoscopes (heat sensitive).

name: Regions of the Abdomen
regions_9:
9 Regions

Divided by Mid-clavicular lines, Transpyloric (L1), and Transtubercular (L5) planes.
  • Right Hypochondrium: Liver, GB.
  • Epigastrium: Stomach, Pancreas.
  • Left Hypochondrium: Spleen.
  • RIF: Appendix, Cecum.
  • LIF: Sigmoid.
  • Hypogastrium: Bladder, Uterus.
planes:
Transpyloric Plane (L1)

Contains: Pylorus, Pancreas neck, SMA origin, Portal vein formation, Renal hila.

name: Anatomy of the Stomach
blood_supply:
Arterial Supply (Celiac Trunk)

  • Lesser Curve: Left Gastric (Celiac) + Right Gastric (Hepatic).
  • Greater Curve: Left Gastroepiploic (Splenic) + Right Gastroepiploic (GDA).
  • Fundus: Short Gastrics (Splenic) - Risk in Splenectomy.
nerves:
Vagus (CN X)

Anterior (Left) & Posterior (Right) trunks.
Nerve of Latarjet: Supplies antrum (motility). Preserved in Highly Selective Vagotomy.

name: Anatomy of Hepatobiliary System
liver:
Couinaud Segments

8 segments based on vascular inflow/outflow. Caudate Lobe (I): Drains directly to IVC.
Blood Supply: 75% Portal Vein, 25% Hepatic Artery.
calots:
Calot's Triangle

Boundaries: Liver edge, Common Hepatic Duct, Cystic Duct.
Content: Cystic Artery.
Moynihan's Hump: Tortuous Right Hepatic Artery looping into triangle (Danger!).

name: Anatomy of Alimentary Tract
small_bowel:
Jejunum vs Ileum

Jejunum: Thick, wide, long vasa recta, few arcades.
Ileum: Thin, Peyer's patches, short vasa recta, fatty mesentery.
colon_supply:
Colon Supply

SMA (Midgut): Ascending/Transverse.
IMA (Hindgut): Descending/Sigmoid.
Watershed Areas: Splenic Flexure (Griffith's) & Rectosigmoid (Sudeck's) - Prone to Ischemia.

name: Inguinal Canal Anatomy
contents:
Male: Spermatic Cord + Ilioinguinal Nerve (On top).
Female: Round Ligament.
clinical:
Deep Ring: Mid-inguinal point (Indirect Hernia).
Hesselbach's Triangle: Medial to Inf Epigastric vessels (Direct Hernia).

name: Femoral Triangle
hernia:
Femoral Hernia

Through Femoral Canal. Below & Lateral to Pubic Tubercle. High strangulation risk (Lacunar ligament).

name: Neck & Thyroid Anatomy
nerves:
Nerves at Risk

Recurrent Laryngeal (RLN): Hoarseness (Unilateral), Airway Obstruction (Bilateral).
External Laryngeal: Loss of high pitch voice.
supply:
Arterial: Superior Thyroid (ECA), Inferior Thyroid (Thyrocervical trunk).
Venous: Sup/Mid -> IJV. Inf -> Brachiocephalic.

name: Amoebic Liver Abscess
clinical:
Features

Entamoeba histolytica. RUQ pain, fever, 'Anchovy Sauce' pus (sterile).
Treatment: Metronidazole 800mg TDS (Cures 90%). Aspiration only if large/risk of rupture.

name: Gastric Outlet Obstruction
metabolic:
Hypochloremic Metabolic Alkalosis

Vomiting acid (HCl). Paradoxical Aciduria (Kidney saves Na+ via H+ excretion).
management:
Resuscitation: 0.9% Saline + K+ (Avoid Hartmann's). NG Decompression.
Definitive: Balloon (Benign) or Stent/Surgery (Malignant).

name: Fistula-in-Ano
classification:
Parks Class

1. Intersphincteric (Commonest). 2. Trans-sphincteric.

Goodsall's Rule

Anterior -> Straight. Posterior -> Curved to midline.

name: Diverticular Disease
complications: 1. Diverticulitis: LIF pain. 2. Perforation: Peritonitis. 3. Bleeding: Massive painless. 4. Fistula: Pneumaturia.

name: Hemorrhoids
clinical:
Internal: Painless bleed (above dentate). External: Painful (below dentate).
Rx: Rubber band (Grade 1/2). Surgery (Grade 3/4).

name: Skin Malignancies
types:
BCC: Rolled edge, pearly. No mets. Rx: Excision.
SCC (Marjolin's): In chronic scars. Aggressive. Mets to nodes. Rx: Wide excision.

name: Flail Chest
pathophysiology: Fracture of 3+ ribs in 2+ places. Paradoxical breathing. Hypoxia due to Pulmonary Contusion + Pain.

name: Intussusception
triad: 1. Colicky pain. 2. Redcurrant jelly stool. 3. Sausage mass (RUQ).

name: Varicocele
clinical: 'Bag of worms'. 90% Left (Renal vein drainage). Red Flag: Sudden onset Left or ANY Right varicocele = Renal Tumor.

name: Keloids vs Hypertrophic Scar
features:
Keloid: Extends beyond wound. No regression. Sternum/Ear. Rx: Steroid injection.
Hypertrophic: Confined to wound. Regresses.
